summary: The Supreme Court of the Colony of the Gambia held that the Bathurst Reform Club, an unincorporated members' club, held the premises on a monthly tenancy after the expiration of a two-year lease, as the rent was expressed as 10 per month rather than an annual sum, thereby rebutting the presumption of a yearly tenancy. The court upheld the validity of the notice to quit given by the landlord. However, the action failed because the individual officers (secretary, president, treasurer) were not proper defendants, as an unincorporated club cannot be sued through its officers without a court order under R.S.C. (Gambia), Ord. 3, r. 3 authorizing representative parties. The claim was dismissed, but no costs were awarded due to initial pleading deficiencies.
verdict: Judgment for the defendants; claim dismissed due to improper parties, though notice to quit was valid.

jurisdiction.court: Supreme Court of the Colony of the Gambia

citations: Ladies' Hosiery and Underwear Ltd. v. Parker [1930] 1 Ch. 304
rationaleHighlights: Rent expressed monthly rebuts presumption of yearly tenancy
Unincorporated club not a legal entity; officers cannot be sued personally without court authorization
R.S.C. (Gambia) Ord. 3 r. 3 requires court-authorized representatives for unincorporated associations
Plaintiff must sue correct parties; burden not on defendant to correct pleading defects
Oral agreement confirmed assignment and new two-year term at monthly rent
